Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Electroencephalography System for Research and Training On Neurophysiology of Language, Cognitive Neuroscience and Neural Plasticity.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Instrumentation Grant award supports the acquisition of an integrated Electroencephalography (EEG) system (ActiChamp 64 active-electrodes, Brain Vision LLC) to establish the first EEG laboratory at the California State Polytechnic University, Pomona (CPP), one of the few undergraduate Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSI) in the US. EEG is a non-invasive neuroimaging technique that allows the monitoring of human cerebral activity with millisecond precision while cognitive processes unfold. The EEG laboratory at CPP will be critical in developing cutting-edge research to study cognition and neural plasticity. A particular research theme will focus on the neurophysiological bases of bilingualism, asking how the cognitive and neural processes that are engaged by the use of two or more languages affect learning and cognition more generally. This award will enable a unique initiative to establish a cross-disciplinary research program in electrophysiology and cognitive neuroscience that will include a number of researchers in Psychology, Bioengineering and Linguistics. The EEG laboratory will also be key in creating a unique research and training consortium between CPP, Pomona College (a nearby research intensive undergraduate institution), and the University of California, Riverside (UCR). Overall, this award will significantly enhance research capacity at CPP, and by doing so, will promote research-training opportunities for CPP's undergraduate students who are predominantly members of underrepresented minorities. The research to be conducted holds the promise to overturn many of the previously held stereotypes about bilingualism, with implications for dual language education and for the potential of bilingualism to protect aging brains.


A major focus of the planned research will investigate the neurophysiological, cognitive and social underpinnings of second language (L2) learning and bilingualism. In the last 30 years, advances in neuroscience have changed understanding of the relationship between language, cognition, and the brain. EEG provides information about what neural activity occurs in response to specific language and cognitive processes with exceptional temporal precision. Because language processing is extremely fast, the most transformative application of EEG has been to capture and distinguish among language and cognitive processes that would have otherwise not been measurable simply by tracking behavior. More specifically, the team will develop research on the cognitive and neural underpinnings of new L2 language learning and consolidation, while analyzing the EEG signal in both time (ERPs) and frequency (TF) domains. Questions related to changes in neural plasticity, network reorganization, and functional connectivity as a function of L2 learning and bilingualism will be investigated looking at the earliest changes in EEG network connectivity, and EEG resting state networks. The goal will be to better understand the overall cognitive and neural implications of bilingualism and L2 learning across the life-span from younger to older adulthood. Finally, the team will exploit a unique feature of bilingualism by investigating the cognitive and neural underpinnings of code-switching between two languages, the practice of mixing two languages that is common in bilingual communities and that holds the potential to reveal new insights into the way that multiple languages are represented in the brain.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Major Instrumentation Grant award supported the acquisition of an integrated Electroencephalography (EEG) system that enabled the establishment of  the first EEG laboratory at the California State Polytechnic University, Pomona (CPP), one of the few undergraduate Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSI) in the US. EEG is a non-invasive technique that allows to record the "electrical brain activity" of the human brain, and is used to understand the neural underpinnings of human cognitive functions such as memory, language, and attention, among others.

 

Intellectual merit: 

EEG is a non-invasive neuroimaging technique that allows the monitoring of human cerebral activity with millisecond precision while cognitive processes, like for example memory and language processing unfold. The EEG laboratory at CPP has been critical to develop cutting-edge research to study cognition and neural plasticity in a number of areas, including language processing, bilingualism and memory.  The newly established EEG lab has enabled to establish a cross-disciplinary research program in electrophysiology and cognitive neuroscience at Cal Poly Pomona, and has enabled to train a large number of undergraduate students. In fact, the  EEG laboratory has created a unique research and training consortium between Cal Poly Pomona, Pomona College (a nearby research intensive undergraduate institution), and the University of California, Riverside (UCR). 

In the first two years of the award, the EEG system has enabled a number of projects, including 1) a large project on the processing of grammar in heritage speakers of Spanish. The data collection was completed last year, and publication of the results is in preparation. For this project 4 undergraduate students were trained and collected the data. 2) A project on understanding how manipulating memory changes the way we process language in real time both in the native and the second language. This project was part of a larger researcher for an undergraduate McNair project. The undergraduate student was also able to collect part of the data at the University of Florida during the 2019 summer. The data for this project are in preparation for publication. 3) A project on understanding the Negative Corrections on Belief in Misinformation during language processing(Prof. Kevin Autry). The purpose of the study is to determine whether the effectiveness of negative corrections is influenced by the initial exposure to the misinformation. Subjects studied true and false trivia statements, received affirmative or negative corrections, and then restudied the correct items while brain activity was measured via EEG. The primary hypothesis is that restudying the correct items will produce a larger N400 when subjects did not read the false statement before the negative correction (i.e., unlicensed negation) than when they did read the false statement first (i.e., licensed negation). This finding would support the idea that context influences the effects of negation and that unlicensed negative corrections may actually increase belief in negated concepts. Over 6 undergraduates were trained for this project. 4) a Study to understand long-term memory retrieval following interactive imagery. In this study, participants are presented with word pairs and asked to perform two different mental imagery strategies that have been previously shown to promote recognition of qualitatively forms of information. Participants were asked to perform an item recognition test during which we record EEG. For this project over 6 undergraduates were trained, and data collection was in progress before the beginning of the Covid-19 pandemic. 

Overall, over the course of the award, the establishment of this lab has significantly impacted research productivity in the Psychology department, and affiliate departments. Unfortunately, in the last year of the award data collection for the whole lab has halted due to the testing restriction Covid-19 pandemic. 

 

Broader impacts: 

A large number of Cal Poly Pomona undergraduate students got trained in the EEG methodology and has enabled them to collaborate with other students at faculties at Pomona College and UCR. The establishment of this laboratory has also had a visible impact on students' placement regarding PhD programs. In the last 2 years four students who have worked in the newly established EEG lab have been accepted to RO1's PhD programs, including UC Davis, University of Florida, and UCSB.
